metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Destructuring
Destructuring Assignment Syntax
The destructuring assignment syntax unpack object properties into variables:
content.html: The destructuring assignment syntax unpack object properties into variables:

content.code_html: let {firstName, lastName} = person;

content.text: It can also unpack arrays and any other iterables:
content.html: It can also unpack arrays and any other iterables:

content.code_html: let [firstName, lastName] = person;

content.text: Object Destructuring

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50
};

// Destructuring
 let {firstName, lastName} = person;

content.text: The order of the properties does not matter:
content.html: The order of the properties does not matter:

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50
};

// Destructuring
 let {lastName, firstName} = person;

content.text: Note:
Destructuring is not destructive.
Destructuring does not change the original object.
content.html: Destructuring does not change the original object.

content.text: Object Default Values
For potentially missing properties we can set default values:
content.html: For potentially missing properties we can set default values:

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50
};

// Destructuring
 let {firstName, lastName, country = "US"} = person;

content.text: Object Property Alias

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50
};

// Destructuring
 let {lastName : name} = person;

content.text: String Destructuring
One use for destructuring is unpacking string characters.
content.html: One use for destructuring is unpacking string characters.

content.code_html:
// Create a String
 let name = "W3Schools";

// Destructuring
 let [a1, a2, a3, a4, a5] = name;

content.text: Note:
Destructuring can be used with any iterables.
content.html: Destructuring can be used with any iterables.

content.text: Array Destructuring
We can pick up array variables into our own variables:
content.html: We can pick up array variables into our own variables:

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const fruits = ["Bananas", "Oranges", "Apples", "Mangos"];

// Destructuring
 let [fruit1, fruit2] = fruits;

content.text: Skipping Array Values
We can skip array values using two or more commas:
content.html: We can skip array values using two or more commas:

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const fruits = ["Bananas", "Oranges", "Apples", "Mangos"];

// Destructuring
 let [fruit1,,,fruit2] = fruits;

content.text: Array Position Values
We can pick up values from specific index locations of an array:
content.html: We can pick up values from specific index locations of an array:

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const fruits = ["Bananas", "Oranges", "Apples", "Mangos"];
// Destructuring
 let {[0]:fruit1 ,[1]:fruit2} = fruits;

content.text: The Rest Property
You can end a destructuring syntax with a rest property.
content.html: You can end a destructuring syntax with a rest property.

content.text: This syntax will store all remaining values into a new array:
content.html: This syntax will store all remaining values into a new array:

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const numbers = [10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70];

// Destructuring
 const [a,b, ...rest] = numbers

content.text: Destructuring Maps

content.code_html:
// Create a Map
 const fruits = new Map([
  ["apples", 500],
  ["bananas", 300],
  ["oranges", 200]
]);

// Destructing
 let text = "";
for (const [key, value] of fruits) {
  text += key + " is " + value;
}

content.text: Swapping JavaScript Variables
You can swap the values of two variables using a destructuring assignment:
content.html: You can swap the values of two variables using a destructuring assignment:

content.code_html:
let firstName = "John";
let lastName = "Doe";

// Destructing
 [firstName, lastName] = [lastName, firstName];

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: const fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry']; let [x, y] = fruits; What will be the value of x ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
const fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry'];
let [x, y] = fruits;
What will be the value of x?

metadata.question: Consider the following code:const fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry'];let [x, y] = fruits;What will be the value of x?

content.question: Consider the following code:const fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry'];let [x, y] = fruits;What will be the value of x?
